text: [Music]
so my name is Jim Ying I head up the
publishing organization at six waves law
laps uh we publisher on both uh social
and mobile a little bit about six waves
uh we publish on Social Mobile and what
does a publisher do in these two places
there's a couple key services that we
provide distribution marketing
localization hosting and game advisory
and so on the distribution and marketing
side we have a network of around 25
million monthly active users across both
platforms any game that joins our
Network we automatically start cross
moding those users in in addition to
that for the games that do perform we
spend th hundreds of thousands if not
millions of dollars pushing those games
um there's also localizations so we
localize into four to five up to nine or
10 different languages uh hosting and
then game advisory so because we do see
such a wide array of games uh our
product team has a good idea what are
the best practices across the various
platforms and so the developers that
work with us we share some of those best
practices uh couple of top games that
we've published mostly on Facebook
there's probably 15 to 17 games that we
pushed to over 1 million monthly active
users there's a handful 456 that we've
done through the 456 million monthly
active user range and then there's uh
Raven Sky City and Ravenwood Fair which
we've pushed to over 10 11 12 million
monthly active
users now to keep it somewhat
interesting and just not a pure pitch I
just want to share a little bit about
what publishing looks like in the social
and mobile space relative to the console
space So I myself spent a couple of
years over at Xbox on the first- party
publishing team working on both Halo and
Age of Empires uh I've been in the
social and mobile space for a year and a
half two years now and a lot of people
ask why publishing necessary in Social
and mobile um definitely while you can
build a great game you still do need
someone to go push traffic to your game
spend marketing doing user acquisition
helping to localize these games and for
a lot of developers we focused on making
that great fun game experience this
isn't stuff that they want to worry
about and so they partner with us and we
take care of all that stuff now a couple
of things that are different between
let's say console publishing traditional
PC game publishing and Social Mobile
publishing
right here so definitely there's
increased data visibility leading to
more transparent Communications between
the publisher developer so what I'm
saying with this is on Facebook on
mobile you can see exactly how your
users are performing after you launched
a game you're constantly looking at the
stats and so both the publisher and the
developer are very aligned with how the
game is doing if the game's not doing
well everyone knows whereas on the
console or PC side the developer makes
the game they basically pitch it over to
the publisher and they don't really see
how the game does until you know let's
say the weekly reports or the monthly
reports come out another one is the Deep
connectivity between the game design and
the distribution and the marketing side
really allows publishing to bring to the
table best practices so because we do
see so many games we see on Facebook
what are the viral features that are
going to spread to users what are the
retention metrics that are going to get
people coming back to your game on
mobile it might be what are the specific
UI changes that we've seen some of our
developers do that make for a better
gameplay experience
these are things that as a publisher we
can bring to the partners whereas you
know on Console generally the developers
know exactly what kind of game they want
to make they're only relying on on the
publisher for the distribution and the
marketing um another one game
development Cycles are fast enough that
when you work with a publisher like us
on soci or mobile you're not signing
away two to three years of work it's
four months six months see how it does
and if the publisher does a good job
then yeah you continue working with them
but if not you know you go off and work
with someone else fortunately for us
we've signed with multiple partners
where we've worked on a couple of games
they've valued what we've been able to
bring to the table and so there's you
know five or six where we've launched
two three four five games with uh and
then finally players at this point are
on multiple social networks they're on
multiple mobile networks really in order
to hit as many of these people as
possible with as many touch points you
want to be working with someone who does
have publishing across all of those
platforms and fortunately we
did and that's it thank you
[Music]
